ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the polyurethane foam manufacturing system. The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of a regulated substance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Carpenter Co. - Lathrop facility maintains and operates a process system comprised of Methyl Formate and Toluene Diisocyanate, 80:20 TDI blend (80 wt% 2,4 TDI and 20 wt% 2,6 TDI) hereby referred to as TDI. Not including unloading of the regulated chemicals Methyl Formate and TDI to their respective storage tanks, there is one process these regulated chemical are involved in.

Chemical injection process for polyurethane foam equipment for the regulated substances involved in the manufacturing of polyurethane foam include: one large TDI storage tank, one large Methyl Formate storage tank, one small Methyl Formate storage tank, two Methyl Formate feed pumps, one Methyl Formate pump metering skid, two heat exchangers, one TDI low pressure feed pump, one TDI high pressure metering pump, and up to two small Methyl Formate ISO containers which can be used in reserve. Both Methyl Formate and TDI are individually piped and do not come into contact with one another until they meet at the mixing head where the foam is poured. Additionally, there can be up to four TDI railcars stored onsite. Details of the inventory calculation can be found in the Process Safety Information (PSI) section of the Compliance Workbook.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated toxic chemical involved in the polyurethane foam

manufacturing process (TDI). The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated toxic chemical involved in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process (TDI). The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

Risk Considerations:
Although both the handling of Methyl Formate and TDI and the production of polyurethane foam have inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a Methyl Formate and/or TDI release. The facility utilizes pressure relief valves, manual and automated shutoffs, and emergency shutdown systems.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of the Prevention Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of Methyl Formate and TDI. Prevention elements for each program are listed in Table 1 below.

ety Review

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of TDI or Methyl Formate at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Carpenter Co. - Lathrop prepares and submits the Hazardous Materials Business Plan and associated Contingency Plans which outlines emergency contacts, spill procedures, onsite chemical inventory and site map. Carpenter Co has an onsite Emergency Response Team(ERT) with its primary mission is to contain and control TDI and Methyl Formate release incidents. They are also trained and equipped to handle all hazmat release incidents within the Lathrop Plant. At a minimum, refresher training occurs annually or when a new member transfers to the team. Training includes activation, response, team assignments, containment and control, proper PPE selection, incident management, proper equipment selection and application, site safety.
The Safety Manager will review the Lathrop Plant Contingency Plan at least annually or when changes or updates are warranted. If any changes are identified, all ERT personnel and manager

s will be briefed on updated sections. The updated Contingency plan is distributed to all personnel and agencies. Revisions are documented as well.
The facility Contingency Plan includes spill notifications both written and verbal including local response agency, San Joaquin County Environmental Health and CalOES Warning Center. In the event of a Regulated Substance release exceeding the Reportable Quantity, the National Response Center is also notified. 
Only qualified trained ERT personnel will use and/or operate emergency response equipment and supplies. All emergency response equipment and supplies are inventoried and inspected quarterly. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The emergency response program, Prevention Program, Covered Process system and equipment inspections, Contractor evaluation and training are key components that will be strongly evaluated. The main focus will ensure effectiveness, compliance and applicability based on current standards, recognized practices and current state and federal regulations.
